question: Which rock transition causes fossils to be destroyed, leading to gaps in the fossil record?

content.source_1: Fossils are predominantly preserved in sedimentary rocks formed from deposited sediments; igneous and metamorphic rocks seldom contain fossils.
content.source_2: During metamorphism, heat, pressure, and fluid alteration typically obliterate original sedimentary features, so fossils are commonly destroyed when sedimentary rocks are metamorphosed.
content.source_3: In the rock cycle, burial and tectonic compression routinely transform sedimentary rocks into metamorphic rocks over wide regions during mountain-building (regional metamorphism).
content.source_4: Unconformities—intervals produced by erosion and/or non-deposition at Earth’s surface—remove portions of the fossil record and can span immense intervals of geologic time.
content.source_5: Weathering and erosion convert exposed sedimentary rock back into sediment and soil, stripping away fossil-bearing layers across broad areas and creating unconformities.
content.source_6: Uplift repeatedly brings sedimentary sequences to the surface, making prolonged erosion pervasive on continents; regional stratigraphic columns commonly include numerous erosional unconformities that excise long fossil sequences.
